misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that closing a Scanner is a mandatory cleanup step for all input sources to prevent resource leaks, not realizing that closing a Scanner wrapped around System.in permanently disables the program's ability to read from the standard input stream.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: System.in is a global singleton resource. Closing a Scanner that wraps it also closes the underlying System.in stream, which prevents any subsequent reads in other parts of the program.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for multiple calls to nextDouble() to function correctly, the user must provide all inputs on a single line of text.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Scanner methods are whitespace-agnostic; they search for the next available token regardless of whether tokens are separated by spaces, tabs, or newlines.
